#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE HOUSE OF MAPUHI
#Text=Despite the heavy clumsiness of her lines , the Aorai handled easily in the light breeze , and her captain ran her well in before he hove to just outside the suck of the surf .
#Text=The atoll of Hikueru lay low on the water , a circle of pounded coral sand a hundred yards wide , twenty miles in circumference , and from three to five feet above high-water mark .
#Text=On the bottom of the huge and glassy lagoon was much pearl shell , and from the deck of the schooner , across the slender ring of the atoll , the divers could be seen at work .
#Text=But the lagoon had no entrance for even a trading schooner .
#Text=With a favoring breeze cutters could win in through the tortuous and shallow channel , but the schooners lay off and on outside and sent in their small boats .
#Text=The Aorai swung out a boat smartly , into which sprang half a dozen brown-skinned sailors clad only in scarlet loincloths .
#Text=They took the oars , while in the stern sheets , at the steering sweep , stood a young man garbed in the tropic white that marks the European .
#Text=The golden strain of Polynesia betrayed itself in the sun-gilt of his fair skin and cast up golden sheens and lights through the glimmering blue of his eyes .
#Text=Raoul he was , Alexandre Raoul , youngest son of Marie Raoul , the wealthy quarter-caste , who owned and managed half a dozen trading schooners similar to the Aorai .
#Text=Across an eddy just outside the entrance , and in and through and over a boiling tide-rip , the boat fought its way to the mirrored calm of the lagoon .
#Text=Young Raoul leaped out upon the white sand and shook hands with a tall native .

#Text=The man 's chest and shoulders were magnificent , but the stump of a right arm , beyond the flesh of which the age-whitened bone projected several inches , attested the encounter with a shark that had put an end to his diving days and made him a fawner and an intriguer for small favors .
#Text=“ Have you heard , Alec ? ” were his first words .
#Text=“ Mapuhi has found a pearl -- such a pearl .
#Text=Never was there one like it ever fished up in Hikueru , nor in all the Paumotus , nor in all the world .
#Text=Buy it from him .
#Text=He has it now .
#Text=And remember that I told you first .
#Text=He is a fool and you can get it cheap .
#Text=Have you any tobacco ? ”
#Text=Straight up the beach to a shack under a pandanus tree Raoul headed .
#Text=He was his mother 's supercargo , and his business was to comb all the Paumotus for the wealth of copra , shell , and pearls that they yielded up .
#Text=He was a young supercargo , it was his second voyage in such capacity , and he suffered much secret worry from his lack of experience in pricing pearls .
#Text=But when Mapuhi exposed the pearl to his sight he managed to suppress the startle it gave him , and to maintain a careless , commercial expression on his face .
#Text=For the pearl had struck him a blow .
#Text=It was large as a pigeon egg , a perfect sphere , of a whiteness that reflected opalescent lights from all colors about it .
#Text=It was alive .
#Text=Never had he seen anything like it .
#Text=When Mapuhi dropped it into his hand he was surprised by the weight of it .
#Text=That showed that it was a good pearl .
#Text=He examined it closely , through a pocket magnifying glass .
#Text=It was without flaw or blemish .
#Text=The purity of it seemed almost to melt into the atmosphere out of his hand .
#Text=In the shade it was softly luminous , gleaming like a tender moon .
#Text=So translucently white was it , that when he dropped it into a glass of water he had difficulty in finding it .
#Text=So straight and swiftly had it sunk to the bottom that he knew its weight was excellent .
#Text=“ Well , what do you want for it ? ” he asked , with a fine assumption of nonchalance .
#Text=“ I want -- ” Mapuhi began , and behind him , framing his own dark face , the dark faces of two women and a girl nodded concurrence in what he wanted .
#Text=Their heads were bent forward , they were animated by a suppressed eagerness , their eyes flashed avariciously .
#Text=“ I want a house , ” Mapuhi went on .
#Text=“ It must have a roof of galvanized iron and an octagon-drop-clock .
#Text=It must be six fathoms long with a porch all around .
#Text=A big room must be in the centre , with a round table in the middle of it and the octagon-drop-clock on the wall .
#Text=There must be four bedrooms , two on each side of the big room , and in each bedroom must be an iron bed , two chairs , and a washstand .
#Text=And back of the house must be a kitchen , a good kitchen , with pots and pans and a stove .
#Text=And you must build the house on my island , which is Fakarava . ”
#Text=“ Is that all ? ”
#Text=Raoul asked incredulously .
#Text=“ There must be a sewing machine , ” spoke up Tefara , Mapuhi 's wife .
#Text=“ Not forgetting the octagon-drop-clock , ” added Nauri , Mapuhi 's mother .
#Text=“ Yes , that is all , ” said Mapuhi .
#Text=Young Raoul laughed .
#Text=He laughed long and heartily .
#Text=But while he laughed he secretly performed problems in mental arithmetic .
#Text=He had never built a house in his life , and his notions concerning house building were hazy .

#Text=While he laughed , he calculated the cost of the voyage to Tahiti for materials , of the materials themselves , of the voyage back again to Fakarava , and the cost of landing the materials and of building the house .
#Text=It would come to four thousand French dollars , allowing a margin for safety -- four thousand French dollars were equivalent to twenty thousand francs .
#Text=It was impossible .
#Text=How was he to know the value of such a pearl ?
#Text=Twenty thousand francs was a lot of money -- and of his mother 's money at that .
